DataElement.preferredName: PSA Doubling Time Month Duration Number
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Number to represent the calculation result of the time in months required for a PSA (Prostate Specific Antigen) value to double in value.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Alternate isoforms of the single-chain 261-aa 30-kD Kallikrein 3 (Prostate Specific Antigen) glycoprotein precursor are encoded by human KLK3 Gene (Kallikrein Family). Frameshifted isoform 2 has a shorter distinct C-terminus. A serine protease in seminal plasma, PSA may function in liquefaction of seminal coagulum by (preferential Tyr-X) cleavage of seminal vesicle protein. Kallikrein proteases have diverse functions. Mounting evidence implicates kallikreins in carcinogenesis; some have potential as cancer biomarkers. The serum level of PSA is useful in diagnosis and monitoring of prostatic carcinoma. (from LocusLink, Swiss-Prot, OMIM, and NCI)_A twofold increase._A twofold increase._the continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Alternate isoforms of the single-chain 261-aa 30-kD Kallikrein 3 (Prostate Specific Antigen) glycoprotein precursor are encoded by human KLK3 Gene (Kallikrein Family). Frameshifted isoform 2 has a shorter distinct C-terminus. A serine protease in seminal plasma, PSA may function in liquefaction of seminal coagulum by (preferential Tyr-X) cleavage of seminal vesicle protein. Kallikrein proteases have diverse functions. Mounting evidence implicates kallikreins in carcinogenesis; some have potential as cancer biomarkers. The serum level of PSA is useful in diagnosis and monitoring of prostatic carcinoma. (from LocusLink, Swiss-Prot, OMIM, and NCI)

Concepts.definition: Prostate-specific antigen (261 aa, ~29 kDa) is encoded by the human KLK3 gene. This protein plays a role in both proteolysis and seminal fluid liquefaction.

Property.preferredDefinition: A twofold increase.:The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past; a specific point in this continuum or the interval separating two points.

Concepts.definition: The continuum of experience in which events pass from the future through the present to the past.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An activity that occurs between organisms or that occurs within an organism and involves the function, or modification of function by external factors, of biologic molecules, biologic complexes, subcellular components, cells, tissues, organs, or organ systems.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Duration of an event expressed in number of months._One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar.  It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks._The period of time during which something continues.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar.  It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.:The period of time during which something continues.:Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
The period of time during which something continues.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.

ReferenceDocuments.name: Calculation Source
ReferenceDocuments.description: PSADT will be calculated using the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center cancer information prostate nomogram for PSA doubling time found at: http://www.mskcc.org/mskcc/applications/nomograms_v2/PSADoublingTime.aspx as recommended in the Prostate Specific Antigen Working Group Guidelines.

ReferenceDocuments.name: NRG_Text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is the PSA doubling time less than 12 months?
